thread.title: Amy Schumer who? Forbes list of highest-paid comedians doesn't include any women
thread.title_full: Amy Schumer who? Forbes list of highest-paid comedians doesn't include any women | syracuse.com

author: Geoff Herbert | gherbert@syracuse.com
title: Amy Schumer who? Forbes list of highest-paid comedians doesn't include any women
text:
"Trainwreck" star Amy Schumer had a huge year, but she's not immune to the gender wage gap.
Forbes' 2015 list of the world's highest-paid comedians features many recognizable names like Jerry Seinfeld and Kevin Hart but no women.
Seinfeld topped the list with $36 million this past year, thanks to syndication (and now streaming) of his namesake sitcom, plus his "Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee" series, a Super Bowl ad and standup comedy performances.
Hart was No. 2 with $28.8 million, thanks to his own successful tours and a slew of movies, including "Think Like a Man Too" and "The Wedding Ringer." Ventriloquists Terry Fator and Jeff Dunham, and "Last Comic Standing" judge Russell Peters rounded out the top 5 with close to $20 million each.
The rest of the top 10 were also all males: Aziz Ansari, Louis C.K., Gabriel Iglesias, John Bishop and Dave Chappelle, who recently returned to the list with $7.5 million.
That means the "Inside Amy Schumer" star, Kathy Griffin, Whoopi Goldberg, Chelsea Handler, Wanda Sykes, Sarah Silverman and other notable comediennes all made less than a fourth as much as Seinfeld did this past year.
Forbes notes that "a pay gap persists" in comedy just like the rest of the entertainment industry, but it's worth noting the list is based on concert ticket sales as a primary source of income. Schumer, Griffin, Goldberg and Handler all earned more through TV and film than standup over the past 12 months.
But Forbes also points out funny females have struggled for decades. Since 1959, only three women have won the Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album: Griffin, Goldberg and Lily Tomlin.
E! adds Jennifer Lawrence recently criticized the "major issue" with an op-ed for Lena Dunham's newsletter. The "Hunger Games" actress shared her disappointment at learning her male "American Hustle" co-stars Bradley Cooper and Jeremy Renner made much more than she did.
Lawrence said she got mad at herself, saying she "failed as a negotiator" because she was afraid of asking for more money and becoming unlikable.
When asked about the pay gap this week, Renner said it's "not my job" to ensure co-stars get paid equally.
2015's highest-paid comedians
1. Jerry Seinfeld: $36 million
2. Kevin Hart: $28.5 million
3. Terry Fator: $21.5 million
4 (tie). Jeff Dunham: $19 million
4 (tie). Russell Peters: $19 million
6. Aziz Ansari: $9.5 million
7. Louis C.K.: $9 million
8. Gabriel Iglesias: $8.5 million
9. John Bishop: $8 million
10. Dave Chappelle: $7.5 million
